FeedItems.Summary:
With the NuGet 1.8 release, we found a breaking change that caused NuGet to fail on Windows XP machines.  Earlier today, we released a hotfix to NuGet 1.8 that addresses this.

FeedItems.Title: NuGet 1.7 Released
FeedItems.Summary: We’re happy to announce that we released NuGet 1.7 today. This release includes several new features as well as over 75 bug fixes. Details are in the NuGet 1.7 Release Notes.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Covert to https URLs in known domains in release notes, description" (#6408) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "[NuGet Symbol Server]Symbols validation status view" (#6407) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This PR adds the support to see the validation status of uploaded symbols. 

Pending validation:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1646506/45246848-7e731d00-b2b8-11e8-8509-4288ee41e0e2.png)

Failed Validations:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1646506/45246849-83d06780-b2b8-11e8-939b-1465dfdfcf3f.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Accessibility] Sign In button improperly labeled for screen readers" (#6406) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Consider re-coding the Sign In button label to be used as a button instead of a tab.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Accessibility] Ensure page elements are properly labeled for use with screen readers" (#6405) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Ensure that expanding headers for buttons have the control for Expand and Collapse set up correctly. Also consider modifying redundant labels that use a header as well as a button.
Eg.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/45246774-fbea5d80-b2b7-11e8-8bc0-321659bb86ad.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Accessibility] Users are confused about the difference between Owners and Organizations" (#6404) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Consider modifying the language around the Owner field to make it clear that an organization can be considered an owner. This could be accomplished with a tooltip, or extra text added to various sections of the site that deal with Owners and/or Organizations.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Accessibility] The action buttons on the packages list is not accessible" (#6403) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We should ensure all page elements can be navigated using a screen reader. Eg: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/45246692-6d75dc00-b2b7-11e8-8cf7-e4f5ae5e0a20.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Users should be given a confirmation message for all tasks completion" (#6402) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Here is the list where we do not:
* When an organization is created, we should state that the organization account was created but needs to be confirmed:
  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/45246565-e32d7800-b2b6-11e8-91c2-c94239354f31.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MDM runners should use secondary DBs" (#6401) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
`NuGet.PackageStatus.Runner` already uses secondary. We should update the other runners to as well:
- `NuGetJobs.StatsReport.Runner`
- `NuGet.Services.Validation.Orchestrator`

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix MSA/AAD login account selection" (#6400) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This fixes https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5150 

The new token option enforces Azure AD auth to show the multiple options for account selection.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Restore: P2P should respect msbuild defined UndefineProperties to avoid global RID from leaking into P2Ps" (#7286) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Came across this when investigating a build failure that @galvesribeiro experienced.
I believe that most users will be unable to identify the problem and come up with a workaround.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): dotnet.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.8.0.6 (`dotnet nuget --version`)

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.401

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 1803, macOS 10.13.6

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: no

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a `netstandard2.0` lib and add `log4net` version `2.0.8` package.
2. Create a `netcoreapp2.1` console app
3. Add a project reference from the console app to the library
4. Publish using `dotnet publish -r win-x64` (or any RID)
<details>
<summary>
5. Observe package downgrade errors
</summary>

```
C:\repos\testsln\testlib\testlib.csproj : error NU1605:  testlib -> log4net 2.0.8 -> System.Threading (>= 4.0.11) [C:\repos\testsln\testcons\testcons.csproj]
C:\repos\testsln\testlib\testlib.csproj : error NU1605: Detected package downgrade: System.Runtime.InteropServices from 4.3.0 to 4.1.0. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.  [C:\repos\testsln\testcons\testcons.csproj]
C:\repos\testsln\testlib\testlib.csproj : error NU1605:  testlib -> log4net 2.0.8 -> System.Net.NameResolution 4.0.0 -> System.Security.Principal.Windows 4.0.0 -> Microsoft.Win32.Primitives 4.0.1 -> runtime.win.Microsoft.Win32.Primitives 4.3.0 -> System.Runtime.InteropServices (>= 4.3.0)  [C:\repos\testsln\testcons\testcons.csproj]
C:\repos\testsln\testlib\testlib.csproj : error NU1605:  testlib -> log4net 2.0.8 -> System.Runtime.InteropServices (>= 4.1.0) [C:\repos\testsln\testcons\testcons.csproj]
```

</details>

## Explanation / Rationale

NuGet and MSBuild evaluate the P2P reference with a different set of global properties.

During `PrepareProjectReferences`, the project reference is marked using `UndefineProperties="TargetFramework;RuntimeIdentifier"` to avoid a global RID from leaking into project references. However, NuGet doesn't respect this logic and evaluates the `PackageReference` items of the P2P using the unmodified set of global properties, thus inadvertently restoring the P2P using the same `-r win-x64` argument and passing the results up the hierarchy.

These all work:
* Building FDD apps instead of SCD
* Adding a `<RuntimeIdentifier>` to the console app
* Any msbuild based workaround involving not needing to pass `-r win-x64`
* Only using the console app and only have log4net in the console app - works for both FDD and SCD publish!

### Sample Project

[testsln.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2362765/testsln.zip)
Do a `dotnet publish -r win-x64` inside the `testcons` folder.

[msbuild.binlog.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2362766/msbuild.binlog.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve NuGet Package Management experience on VS" (#7284) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
There a list of issues with the current NuGet Package Manager UI. This Epic tries to capture all of them.

## Unified Packages List
* Almost always end up with the incorrect tab (Browse vs. Installed vs. Updates)
   * https://twitter.com/sebastienros/status/1037741105792442368
* Shows a limited set of packages - unnecessary large cards with useless information

## Confusing `Package Source` dropdown
* Package results list do not show the source(s) a given package (in the search list) is available at
* The Sources drop-down is confusing
	* Not applicable to all the tabs
	* While installing a package against a particular source, the dependencies are installed from any of the listed source(s) in nuget.config
* Not easy to disable some sources easily/temporarily

## Settings
* The NuGet settings does not show the applicable nuget.config, nor does it allow modifying a given nuget.config
* The solution needs to be reopened for any changes to reflect changes to nuget.config(s)

## Managing packages at a solution
* The current experience for package management for a solution is confusing/non-trivial with check-boxes
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/45238544-06e0c600-b297-11e8-8b78-1ed278fb9ca0.png)
* The consolidate tab experience is also non-intuitive
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/45238592-2f68c000-b297-11e8-9810-d604b143fb94.png)

* New experience needed for [Central Package Version Management](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6764)

## UI Hangs
* There have been many instances of PM UI getting hung while updating/installing packages
   * [Blog post comment](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/2018/07/31/how-to-convince-your-management-to-upgrade-to-visual-studio-2017-for-c-and-cpp-developers/#comment-304075)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Handle signed packages SHA for post restore validation with project lock file" (#7283) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we write down SHA of signed packages with the signature file which is different than the original SHA of the same package when it's not signed when we extract a package on disk either as part of install or restore. This will potentially break our SHA validation as part of post restore operation with repeatable build (project lock file) feature because then if a lock file already has a unsgined package SHA and later that package is repo signed by nuget.org, then any further restore validation will fail which will also fail the restore operation.

So there are multiple suggestions to solve this issue, such as:
- Write the original SHA of the package avoiding Signature file so that it's consistent with unsigned package. That way we won't need to change at multiple places but the down side is it will break existing 4.6 to 4.8 clients so we'd need to ask customers to clean their NuGet global packages folder before opting into project lock fle.

- Another option is to create a new SHAFile to keep track of original SHA of the package and use that to validate post restore. This will have the advantage to not break existing clients and not needed to clean global packages folder but the downside is that we'd need to change at multiple places starting the way we figure out if package is coming from global packages folder or not, then extraction of the package, and finally the validation.

- 3rd option is to continue with the existing code of writing SHA, but change the way we validate SHA of signed packages. So for signed packages, instead of using SHA from the assets file, we use SignUtility apis to get the original SHA and compare that wrt lock file. This will work with existing clients as well as won't need to change at too many places but the downside is to retrieve original SHA of the package specially when package is Author + Repo signed.

- more options.....

@anangaur @rrelyea @PatoBeltran @dtivel

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Restore a project with platform x64" (#7269) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet Version: 4.8.1.5435
msbuild version '15.8.168.64424'

Hi,
when i restore the following project MyProject.csproj
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net46</TargetFramework>
    <Platforms>x64</Platforms>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>
```
with the command ``nuget restore MyProject.csproj`` it creates a ".NETFramework,Version=v4.6/win7-x86" target in the project.assets.json. I would expect an entry for ".NETFramework,Version=v4.6/win7-x64".

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enable SHA tracking and enforcement for Packages.Config scenarios" (#7281) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We'd like to enable Packages.Config scenarios to track and enforce SHA.

For PackageReference users, project lock file will enable SHA enforcement. 
We are exploring either:
1) adding SHA as a new Attribute of the Package element in Packages.Config
2) adding lock file to Packages.Config scenarios.

@zivkan

Events.RelatedBody:
**Description:**
I added an invalid nuget source and then added a nugget package with an old version in the project. I then closed the solution and reopened it. The package showed an update available and installed it successfully without a warning.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create an application.
2. Add a Package source with Invalid URL
3. Add a package to project having update available. for ex NUnit 2.6.1

The package updated successfully.
